title: Judge gives go-ahead to Uber lawsuit
text:
Klarna opens its tills in the US 
A California judge has given the go-ahead to a class-action lawsuit against ride-hailing app Uber , in an employment law case that could prove make-or-break for large parts of the “sharing economy”. 
The case will determine whether some 160,000 Uber drivers in California should be treated as full employees of the company rather than contractors. 
If Uber were forced to take on the full costs of employing its drivers, it could weaken the economic model of one of the most highly valued tech start-ups, and set a precedent that would threaten other companies that rely on organising an army of freelance workers. 
The labour costs for most sharing-economy companies would rise by between 25 and 40 per cent if they were forced to switch from being simple marketplaces to full-service companies, said Andrei Hagiu, an associate professor at Harvard Business School. 
“If I was an entrepreneur that was doing a marketplace for services, I would be looking at this very carefully,” he said. “This is just the first step, but it’s non-trivial.” 
District Court Judge Edward Chen ruled late on Tuesday in San Francisco that the lawsuit, brought by four Uber drivers, should proceed as a class-action case representing anyone who has driven for Uber in California since 2009. We’ll most likely appeal [against] the decision as [drivers] use Uber on their own terms, and there really is no typical driver — the key question at issue 
- Uber 
Uber said it was “not surprised” by the decision and welcomed the fact he had denied some of the class-action claims. It added: “We’ll most likely appeal [against] the decision as [drivers] use Uber on their own terms, and there is no typical driver — the key question at issue.” 
The burden will now be on the company to “disprove an employment relationship”, Judge Chen wrote in a 68-page ruling. The most significant issue in determining if workers should be treated as employees concerned whether Uber had the “right to control work details”, he added. 
A number of class-action suits have been brought against tech start-ups that use large groups of contractors, including Lyft, a rival ride-sharing app; Handy, an app for finding cleaners; and Washio, a mobile laundry service. 
The risk of being found to have misclassified workers as contractors — and of being forced to foot the bill later for the full employment costs — has prompted a number of similar companies to give employee status to some or all of their workers in recent weeks. These include Shyp, a parcel service, and Instacart, a grocery delivery service. Copyright The Financial Times Limited 2015. You may share using our article tools.
